questions.text: At what age does a child attain half-height of the adult height? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 20-24 months

 

  • Children attain half of their adult height by the age of 20-24 months.
  • For children under 2 years of age, length is measured with the help of  an infantometer or rigid measuring table. The infant's head is held firmly against a fixed upright headboard, legs are straightened, and feet are at right angles to legs with toes pointing upwards. The length of the baby is measured from a scale set in the measuring table.
  • Measuring the length of a child lying on a mattress or using cloth tapes is inaccurate and not recommended.
  • Height is measured by asking the child to stand upright with heels, buttocks, shoulder blades, and back of the head in contact with a vertical surface such as a wall, height measuring rod, or a stadiometer. The child should look directly forward, and the headpiece is kept firmly over the head to compress the hair.

 

The growth and development of a child between the age of 18 - 24 months can be classified as,

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Children typically attain half of their adult height by 20-24 months, a critical milestone in early childhood growth and development.

questions.text: A woman with a history of painful genital ulcers 1 year back has a neonate of 1 week who has lesions on face and body with neurological symptoms. What is the likely infection? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HSV (Herpes Simplex Virus)

 

The question presents a scenario where a woman has a history of painful genital ulcers and has given birth to a neonate who now exhibits lesions on the face and body along with neurological symptoms. This clinical picture strongly suggests a neonatal herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection.

 

  • Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) is known to cause painful genital ulcers in adults. The virus can remain latent in the body and reactivate later. During pregnancy or delivery, HSV can be transmitted to the neonate, particularly during vaginal delivery if there are active lesions or viral shedding. Neonatal HSV infection can present with vesicular lesions on the skin, eyes, and mouth, and it may also involve the central nervous system, leading to neurological symptoms. Neonatal HSV infection is a serious condition that requires prompt antiviral treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Toxoplasma: Incorrect because it does not cause painful genital ulcers in the mother or the described symptoms in the neonate.

 

Option B. Varicella: Incorrect because, although it can cause skin lesions in neonates, it is not linked with a history of painful genital ulcers in the mother.

 

Option D. CMV: Incorrect because CMV can cause congenital infections with neurological symptoms, but it is not associated with painful genital ulcers in the mother.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A history of painful genital ulcers in the mother, especially when associated with neonatal lesions and neurological symptoms, is highly suggestive of neonatal HSV infection. HSV is a serious condition that requires immediate medical attention to prevent severe outcomes in the neonate.

questions.text: A patient presented with case of diarrhea after eating sea food/ oyster, showing Kanagawa phenomenon. What is the causative organism? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vibrio parahemolyticus

 

Explanation:

 

Vibrio parahemolyticus causes Food-borne gastroenteritis

 

  • MC presentation
  • Following uncooked sea food (e.g. Oyster and shellfish) intake.
  • Watery diarrhea (MC), dysentery, abdominal cramps.
  • Extraintestinal manifestations → wound infection, otitis and sepsis.

 

 

Bipolar staining – safety pin appearance is seen in 5 bacteria’s –

 

Mnemonic

 

 

Note - Kanagawa phenomenon

 

  • V. parahaemolyticus  produce Beta  hemolysis on special blood agar medium → called the Wagatsuma agar
  • Wagatsuma agar  → High-salt (7%) blood agar (defibrinated human or rabbit blood) medium containing d-mannitol as the carbohydrate source.
  • Hemolysis observed on Wagatsuma agar medium, referred to as the Kanagawa phenomenon (KP).

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vibrio cholera: Causes cholera, characterized by severe watery diarrhea but not typically associated with the Kanagawa phenomenon.

 

Option C. E. coli: Can cause gastroenteritis but is not associated with the Kanagawa phenomenon.

 

Option D. Vibrio vulnificus: Can cause severe infections from seafood consumption but is not typically associated with the Kanagawa phenomenon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vibrio parahemolyticus is the causative organism of gastroenteritis following the consumption of uncooked seafood, identified by the Kanagawa phenomenon. The most common symptoms are watery diarrhea, dysentery, and abdominal cramps.

 

Additional Information -

 

Classification based on Salt Requirement

 

1. Nonhalophilic vibrios:

  • Can grow without salt but 1% salt is optimum for their growth.
  • Cannot grow at higher salt concentrations.
  • Examples → V. cholerae and V. mimicus

 

2. Halophilic vibrios: 

  • Cannot grow in the absence of salt.
  • Can tolerate and grow at higher salt concentration of up to 7–10%.  Examples  → V.   parahaemolyticus, V. alginolyticus and V. vulnificus.

questions.text: Which of the following substances is used for sample collection in a tube for blood alcohol concentration measurement? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sodium fluoride + Potassium dichromate

 

Blood alcohol concentration (BAC) can be measured through various methods, including gas chromatography. For accurate measurement of BAC, the blood sample is typically collected in a gray-top vial. This vial contains a mixture of sodium fluoride and potassium oxalate.

 

Sodium fluoride acts as a preservative and prevents glycolysis, which could otherwise lower the concentration of alcohol in the blood sample.

 

However, when using the potassium dichromate test for BAC, potassium dichromate is included in the sample collection tube. In this test, potassium dichromate, which is orange in color, reacts with ethanol present in the blood sample. This reaction converts ethanol to acetic acid and simultaneously reduces potassium dichromate to chromium, which turns the solution green. The intensity of the green color directly correlates with the alcohol concentration in the sample, providing a visual indication of BAC.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heparin + EDTA: This combination is generally used as an anticoagulant in blood samples for various laboratory tests but is not specifically used for BAC measurement.

 

Option C. Heparin: While heparin is an anticoagulant, it is not used in the collection tubes for blood alcohol concentration testing.

 

Option D. Sodium citrate: Sodium citrate is also an anticoagulant, commonly used in coagulation studies, but it is not relevant for BAC measurement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sodium fluoride and potassium dichromate are the substances used in the tube for blood alcohol concentration measurement. Potassium dichromate reacts with ethanol in the blood sample, facilitating the detection and quantification of alcohol concentration

choices.text: Kills the sperms in the cervical canal

questions.text: Which of the following is not the mechanism of action of progesterone only pills? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Kills the sperms in the cervical canal

 

Explanation:

 

Progesterone only pills (POPs), also known as mini pills, act through several mechanisms to prevent pregnancy, but they do not kill sperms in the cervical canal.

 

Incorrect. Progesterone only pills do not have a spermicidal effect. They do not kill sperm; instead, they work by altering the cervical mucus and preventing ovulation.

 

The mechanisms of action include:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thickening the cervical mucus: This makes it difficult for sperm to enter the uterus and fertilize an egg.

 

Option B. Preventing ovulation: Although not as consistently as combined oral contraceptives, POPs can inhibit ovulation in some women.

 

Option D. Inhibiting penetration of sperm: By thickening the cervical mucus and affecting the endometrial lining, POPs inhibit the sperm’s ability to penetrate and fertilize an egg.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Progesterone only pills prevent pregnancy by thickening cervical mucus, inhibiting ovulation, and preventing sperm penetration, but they do not kill sperm in the cervical canal.

 

Ref: Page no 323, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden onset of chest pain shooting to the neck and interscapular region. X-ray shows widened mediastinum. BP is 110/90 mmHg in the right upper limb and 160/100 mmHg in the left upper limb. What is the most likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute aortic dissection

 

  • Patient with sudden-onset severe chest pain, with a difference in blood pressure between the two limbs, and a widened mediastinum on x-ray suggests a diagnosis of acute aortic dissection.
  • AORTIC DISSECTION is tear in intima of aorta

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute Coronary Syndrome (ACS): ACS includes conditions such as myocardial infarction and unstable angina. These conditions typically present with chest pain but do not usually cause blood pressure discrepancies between limbs or a widened mediastinum.

 

Option B. Acute Pulmonary Embolism: Pulmonary embolism presents with sudden onset dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, and signs of right heart strain. It does not typically present with blood pressure discrepancies between limbs or a widened mediastinum.

 

Option D. Esophageal Rupture: Esophageal rupture can present with severe chest pain, subcutaneous emphysema, and signs of sepsis. It does not typically present with blood pressure discrepancies between limbs. It may cause mediastinal widening but would more likely present with other signs such as subcutaneous emphysema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The classic presentation of acute aortic dissection includes sudden severe chest pain radiating to the neck and back, a discrepancy in blood pressure between the limbs, and a widened mediastinum on chest X-ray.
  • Immediate imaging with a CT thoracic angiogram and lowering blood pressure are crucial steps in management.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presented with sudden onset of fatigue due to severe anemia, multiple bruises on his limbs, and WBC count of 40,000/cm³. What is the likely karyotype of the child? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 47XX (+21)

 

The clinical presentation of sudden onset fatigue, severe anemia, multiple bruises, and elevated white blood cell count is indicative of acute leukemia, most likely acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), which is the most common type of leukemia in children.

 

Among genetic conditions, Down syndrome (trisomy 21) significantly increases the risk of developing acute leukemias, including ALL and acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

 

Patients with Down syndrome have a particularly high predisposition to acute megakaryocytic leukemia, a subtype of AML, and ALL. Therefore, the karyotype 47XX (+21) aligns with the clinical scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 46XY t (9;22): This karyotype represents the Philadelphia chromosome, commonly associated with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) rather than acute leukemia in children.

 

Option B. 45X0: This karyotype indicates Turner syndrome, characterized by the presence of a single X chromosome and not associated with an increased risk of leukemia.

 

Option D. 46XY: This karyotype represents a normal male individual, which does not align with the clinical presentation of a child with leukemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Children with Down syndrome (trisomy 21) are at an increased risk for developing acute leukemia, making karyotype 47XX (+21) a significant factor in such presentations.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding sirtuins? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Increases insulin sensitivity and thus glucose metabolism.
  2. Promotes genes that increase longevity.
  3. They are of 7 types.
  4. They are one of the types of histone deacetylases.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Sirtuins are a family of proteins that have been widely studied for their role in regulating various cellular processes, including aging, metabolism, and stress responses. Here's a detailed breakdown of each statement:

 

  1. Increases insulin sensitivity and thus glucose metabolism: Sirtuins, particularly SIRT1, have been shown to enhance insulin sensitivity and promote glucose metabolism, which is crucial for maintaining energy homeostasis.
  2. Promotes genes that increase longevity: Sirtuins are known to regulate gene expression in ways that promote longevity. They are involved in the deacetylation of proteins that contribute to cell survival, repair, and metabolism, which are associated with extended lifespan in various organisms.
  3. They are of 7 types: There are seven known sirtuins in humans, designated SIRT1 through SIRT7, each with specific functions in different cellular compartments.
  4. They are one of the types of histone deacetylases: Sirtuins function as NAD+-dependent deacetylases, a class of enzymes that remove acetyl groups from histone and non-histone proteins, influencing gene expression and protein activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sirtuins are a family of seven histone deacetylases involved in increasing insulin sensitivity, glucose metabolism, promoting genes associated with longevity, and playing a significant role in various cellular processes.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male with history of intermittent evening rise of temperature and weight loss has presented with a flexion deformity of the right hip. He had occasional low back ache and on examination, there was hyper reflex on knee jerk. Identify the marked structure responsible to be involved in this pathology:(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4

 

  • Mark 4 shows Psoas major muscle. 
  • This could be a case of tuberculosis of the spine most probably at the level of T12-L1 with psoas abscess. 
  • Iliopsoas muscle is the main flexor of the hip and is attached to the lesser trochanter distal to the hip joint. 
  • Therefore, any irritation to the same can lead to formation of flexion deformity at the hip. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1. Gluteus medius: It take origin from medial surface of iliac part of hip bone. It lies deep and anterior to gluteus maximus.

 

Option B. 2. Gluteus minimus takes origin from the outer surface of the ilium, specifically between the anterior and inferior gluteal lines.

 

Option C. 3. Iliacus muscles takes origin from medial surface of iliac part of hip bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

History of intermittent evening rise of temperature and weight loss with flexion deformity of the right hip, occasional low back ache and hyper reflex on knee jerk are suggestive of tuberculosis of the spine with psoas abscess.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of chronic alcohol use is admitted to the hospital. He presents with anxiety, tremors, and agitation after his last drink 24 hours ago. Which of the following medications is most appropriate for control of alcohol withdrawal symptoms? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lorazepam

 

 

Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine, a class of medications that act as central nervous system depressants, similar to alcohol. In cases of alcohol withdrawal, benzodiazepines are the first-line treatment because they help alleviate symptoms by enhancing GABAergic activity, which is reduced during alcohol withdrawal. This helps to stabilize the central nervous system, reducing anxiety, tremors, and agitation.

 

Among benzodiazepines, lorazepam is preferred, especially in patients with liver disease, because it does not undergo hepatic metabolism to active metabolites, making it safer in individuals with compromised liver function.

 

Other benzodiazepines such as chlordiazepoxide or diazepam may also be used, but lorazepam is often chosen in clinical scenarios where hepatic function is a concern.

 

Other sympatholytic drugs to manage withdrawal symptoms  – Beta blockers; Clonidine and Lofexidine

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fomepizole: This is an alcohol dehydrogenase inhibitor used primarily in the treatment of methanol or ethylene glycol poisoning. It is not indicated for the treatment of alcohol withdrawal symptoms.

 

Option C. Disulfiram: Disulfiram is used as a deterrent in alcohol dependence by causing an unpleasant reaction when alcohol is consumed. However, it is not used to manage withdrawal symptoms and is contraindicated in acute alcohol withdrawal.

 

Option D. Buspirone: Buspirone is an anxiolytic that is used to treat generalized anxiety disorder. It is not effective in managing alcohol withdrawal symptoms and does not have the CNS depressant properties needed to alleviate withdrawal symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:         

 

Lorazepam is the most appropriate medication for managing alcohol withdrawal symptoms due to its CNS depressant effects and safety profile, particularly in patients with liver impairment.

choices.text: A, B, C, D
A, C, D

questions.text:
Which of the following can be used to calculate the cardiac output? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. ECHO.
  2. Ventilation-perfusion scan.
  3. Thermodilution.
  4. Fick's principle
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A, C, D

 

Fick principle, thermodilution, and ECHO can be used to measure cardiac output.

 

Cardiac output is the amount of blood pumped by the heart into the aorta every minute. The average cardiac output is 5L/min and can be measured by various indirect methods.

 

Option A. Doppler echocardiography is a method for detecting the direction and velocity of moving blood within the heart. This is also a popular method to measure cardiac output.

 

Option C. Thermodilution method - a known volume of cold sterile solution is injected into the right atrium via inferior vena cava by using a catheter. Cardiac output is measured by determining the resultant change in the blood temperature in pulmonary artery. For this purpose, two thermistors (temperature transducers) are used. One of them is placed in the inferior vena cava and the second one is placed in pulmonary artery. A pulmonary artery catheter is used to place the thermistors in their positions.

 

Option D. The Fick principle, as applied to cardiac output, relies on the recognition that the total uptake of oxygen by the peripheral tissues is equal to the product of the blood flow to the peripheral tissues and the arterial-venous oxygen concentration difference.

Formula:

 

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Indirect methods used to measure cardiac output:

 

  1. By using Fick principle
  2. Indicator (dye) dilution technique
  3. Thermodilution technique
  4. Ultrasonic Doppler transducer technique
  5. Doppler echocardiography
  6. Ballisto cardiography.

choices.text: Acute coronary syndrome with low EF

questions.text: Automatic implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (AICD) implantation is done for which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. All of the above

 

An Automatic Implantable Cardioverter-Defibrillator (AICD) is used for the prevention of sudden cardiac death in patients with various cardiac conditions that predispose them to life-threatening arrhythmias. The indications include:

 

Option A. Brugada syndrome: A genetic disorder that can lead to dangerous ventricular arrhythmias.

 

Option B. Ventricular fibrillation (VF): A life-threatening heart rhythm that results in rapid, inadequate heartbeats.

 

Option C. Acute coronary syndrome (ACS) with low ejection fraction (EF): After a myocardial infarction, patients with significantly reduced EF are at higher risk for ventricular arrhythmias.

 

The device is particularly beneficial in patients with structural heart disease, prior myocardial infarction, and those who have experienced syncope due to undetermined reasons but are found to have inducible ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation during electrophysiological studies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Class I Indications for AICD implantation:

 

  1. LV dysfunction with ejection fraction less than or equal to 35% and NYHA II/III symptoms.
  2. LV dysfunction with ejection fraction less than or equal to 35% due to previous Myocardial Infarction (MI) or at least 40 days post-MI and NYHA II/III symptoms.
  3. LV dysfunction with ejection fraction less than or equal to 30% due to previous Myocardial Infarction (MI) or at least 40 days post-MI.
  4. LV dysfunction with ejection fraction less than or equal to 40% due to previous Myocardial Infarction (MI) or at least 40 days post-MI and inducible VT/VF on EP study (EPS).
  5. Syncope of unknown etiology and inducible VT/ VF on EPS.
  6. Sustained VT in the presence of structural heart disease.
  7. Brugada syndrome.
  8. HCM with > 1 risk factor for SCD.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Ventricular Arrhythmias/Chapter 252

questions.text:
Arrange the following steps of ventricular action potential in the correct order: (INICET Nov 2022)

 

  1. Opening of voltage-gated calcium channels
  2. Repolarizing K+ currents
  3. Opening of voltage-gated sodium channels
  4. Transient outward flow of potassium
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C, D, A, B

 

The ventricular action potential is characterized by a sequence of changes in membrane potential and ionic currents. The correct sequence is as follows:

 

  1. C. Opening of voltage-gated sodium channels: This is the initial depolarization phase (Phase 0). When the membrane potential reaches the threshold, voltage-gated sodium channels open, leading to a rapid influx of Na+ ions and a sharp rise in membrane potential.
  2. D. Transient outward flow of potassium: This corresponds to Phase 1. Shortly after the peak of the action potential, transient outward K+ channels open, causing a brief efflux of K+ ions which results in a slight repolarization.
  3. A. Opening of voltage-gated calcium channels: This is Phase 2, the plateau phase. Voltage-gated L-type calcium channels open, allowing Ca2+ to enter the cell. The influx of Ca2+ is balanced by the efflux of K+ through delayed rectifier K+ channels, maintaining a plateau in the membrane potential.
  4. B. Repolarizing K+ currents: This is Phase 3. The Ca2+ channels close, but the delayed rectifier K+ channels remain open, leading to a net efflux of K+ and returning the membrane potential to its resting value.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence for ventricular action potential is as follows:

 

C. Opening of voltage-gated sodium channels

D. Transient outward flow of potassium

A. Opening of voltage-gated calcium channels

B. Repolarizing K+ currents

questions.text:
An unconscious child is brought to the casualty. What is the correct sequence of the management? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Assess breathing
  2. Assess pulse
  3. Assess response
  4. Start compressions
  5. Bag and mask ventilation
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3-1-2-4-5

 

When managing an unconscious child, especially in a potential cardiac or respiratory arrest scenario, it is crucial to follow the steps of Basic Life Support (BLS) in the correct sequence to ensure the best chance of recovery.

 

 

Sequence Justification:

 

  • The correct sequence is 3-1-2-4-5, which means:
    • 3: First, assess response (to determine unresponsiveness).
    • 1: Then assess breathing (to check for normal breathing).
    • 2: Followed by assessing the pulse (to check for circulation).
    • 4: Start compressions if necessary (if no pulse or poor perfusion).
    • 5: Provide bag and mask ventilation to support breathing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In BLS, the correct sequence of actions is crucial for effective management. Start by assessing response, followed by breathing and pulse, then initiate compressions and ventilation as needed.

questions.text: A child was brought to ENT OPD with complaints of mouth breathing and snoring from a long duration. He also asks to increase the volume of TV while watching. What is the best treatment for this child’s condition? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Adenoidectomy and grommet

 

The child presents with symptoms of mouth breathing and snoring, which are indicative of adenoid hypertrophy. The request to increase the TV volume suggests a hearing problem, likely due to conductive hearing loss caused by chronic adenoiditis with adenoid hypertrophy. Enlarged adenoids can obstruct the Eustachian tube, leading to fluid accumulation in the middle ear, known as otitis media with effusion. This condition causes conductive hearing loss.

 

Adenoidectomy involves the surgical removal of the adenoids to alleviate the obstruction. Inserting a grommet (tympanostomy tube) allows for drainage of the middle ear fluid, improving hearing and preventing recurrent otitis media.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenoidectomy: While this addresses the adenoid hypertrophy, it does not address the fluid accumulation in the middle ear. The addition of a grommet is necessary for complete management.

 

Option B. Antibiotics: Antibiotics alone would not resolve the underlying issue of adenoid hypertrophy and chronic Eustachian tube obstruction.

 

Option C. Wait and watch: This approach would not be suitable given the chronic nature of the symptoms and the associated hearing loss. Delaying treatment could lead to further complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of chronic adenoid hypertrophy causing mouth breathing, snoring, and conductive hearing loss, the best treatment involves adenoidectomy along with the insertion of a grommet to ensure proper drainage of middle ear fluid and restore normal hearing.

questions.text: A person undergoing Anti PD1 immunotherapy (Nivolumab) presents with itching, eczema, and hives-like rashes. Upon histopathological analysis, a blister beneath the outer skin layer is observed. The direct immunofluorescence assessment of the affected areas indicates the presence of Linear C3 and IgG along the basement membrane. What is the diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bullous pemphigoid

 

BULLOUS PEMPHIGOID

 

  • Immunobullous disease with a sub epidermal split
  • IgG is the autoantibody deposited
  • Target protein: Hemi desmosomes
  • Target antigens: BPAG 2 > 1
  • No acantholysis
    • Clinical Features: Involves primary lesions (Tense pruritic bullae on Erythematous skin or normal skin) and secondary lesions (Itchy Bullae → Erosions due to scratching).
    • Sites: Trunk, abdomen, flexural aspects of extremities, 10-30% of patients have oral erosions.

 

 

  • Investigation:

 

1. Tzanck smear: Presence of eosinophils and Absence of acantholytic cells.

 

2. Histopathology:

 

 

3. Direct Immunofluorescence: show IgG, C3 linear deposits along Basement Membrane Zone.

 

 

  • Treatment: Topical steroids

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pemphigus Vulgaris: Involves intraepidermal blisters and suprabasal acantholysis (separation of skin cells), which are not described in the provided scenario. Direct Immunofluorescence would typically show intercellular deposits, not linear along the basement membrane.

 

Option C. Dermatitis Herpetiformis: Characterized by intensely itchy blisters and associated with gluten sensitivity. Direct Immunofluorescence shows granular IgA deposits at the tips of dermal papillae, not the linear deposition along the basement membrane.

 

Option D. Pemphigus Foliaceous: Presents with superficial (epidermal) blisters that do not affect the deeper layers of the skin. The immunofluorescence pattern would not show the linear deposition along the basement membrane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bullous Pemphigoid in patients undergoing immunotherapy is critical due to the potential severity of the condition and the need for prompt and effective management to reduce symptoms and prevent complications. Monitoring for new or worsening symptoms in patients on immunotherapy is essential to catch such reactions early.

questions.text: Identify the chest x-ray finding shown below. (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lung collapse

 

A collapse can occur when part of the lung becomes airless and typically appears as an area of increased density. The X-ray provided shows a significant opacity along with volume loss, evidenced by the displacement of interlobar fissures and the mediastinum ipsilaterally, which is suggestive of collapse. This is often accompanied by compensatory hyperinflation in the unaffected areas.

 

The chest X-ray shows a significant abnormality in the lung field, suggestive of a lung collapse (atelectasis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Consolidation:  On an X-ray, consolidation typically appears as a uniform increase in pulmonary parenchymal opacity, which may obscure the lung markings and can sometimes involve an entire lobe. Air bronchograms (air-filled bronchi made visible by the opaque alveoli around them) may be visible. There is no mediastinal shift which is typically associated.

 

Option B. Effusion: On an X-ray, this typically shows as a blunting of the costophrenic angles, with fluid layering dependently and possibly causing a meniscus sign along the chest wall. With contralateral mediastinal shift

 

Option D. Intrathoracic Mass Lesion: A mass would typically appear as a well-defined area of increased density, which might push against or compress adjacent structures. The image does not clearly show such characteristics, as the opacity seems too extensive and involves a loss of volume rather than a discrete mass pushing on surrounding tissues.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The opacity and associated signs of volume loss indicate that part of the lung has collapsed, likely due to an obstruction or compression of the airways.

questions.text: Oxygen sensitive channels in peripheral chemoreceptors are for which of the following ion? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) K+

 

Peripheral chemoreceptors are specialized sensory receptors located in the carotid and aortic bodies that detect changes in blood oxygen levels. These receptors play a critical role in the respiratory control by responding to hypoxia (low oxygen levels). The oxygen-sensitive channels in these receptors are specifically sensitive to potassium ions (K+). When oxygen levels drop, these potassium channels close, which leads to a series of events: membrane depolarization, calcium influx, and ultimately, the release of neurotransmitters like ATP. This process triggers signals that increase respiratory activity to raise blood oxygen levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Na+: Sodium channels are important in many physiological processes, but they are not specifically sensitive to oxygen levels in peripheral chemoreceptors.

 

Option C. HCO3-: Bicarbonate ions are involved in acid-base balance and CO2 transport but are not directly involved in the oxygen sensing mechanism of peripheral chemoreceptors.

 

Option D. Cl-: Chloride ions play roles in various cellular processes, including maintaining osmotic balance, but they are not the primary ions involved in oxygen sensing in peripheral chemoreceptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary ion involved in oxygen sensing in peripheral chemoreceptors is potassium (K+). The closure of oxygen-sensitive potassium channels during hypoxia is a crucial step in the signaling pathway that regulates respiratory response to low oxygen levels.

questions.text: Identify the type of transport across the cell membrane represented below? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Facilitated diffusion

 

Explanation:

 

The image depicts the process of facilitated diffusion. This type of transport involves the use of carrier proteins embedded in the cell membrane to help molecules that cannot readily diffuse through the lipid bilayer move across the membrane, down their concentration gradient, without the expenditure of cellular energy (ATP).

 

  • Facilitated Diffusion: This process helps molecules move from an area of higher concentration to one of lower concentration via specific carrier proteins. It is a passive transport method since it does not require energy from ATP but relies on the concentration gradient.
  • Carrier Proteins: These proteins undergo a change in shape to transport molecules across the membrane. They are specific to the substances they transport, ensuring selective and regulated transport into and out of the cell.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Simple Diffusion: Involves the movement of molecules directly through the phospholipid bilayer without the assistance of membrane proteins, driven solely by their concentration gradient.

 

Option C. Primary Active Transport: Requires ATP to move substances against their concentration gradient via pumps.

 

Option D. Secondary Active Transport: Also known as co-transport, uses the gradient of one molecule to move another molecule against its gradient, indirectly using energy but not directly using ATP.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A mother brought her 14-year-old mentally retarded child with complaints of joint pain and an irresistible urge to bite his fingers and lips. On investigation, his serum uric acid level was found to be elevated. The child is likely suffering from which disorder? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lesch-Nyhan syndrome


Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by a complete deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT). This enzyme plays a critical role in the purine salvage pathway, where it helps recycle hypoxanthine and guanine back into nucleotides rather than allowing them to degrade into uric acid. In the absence of HGPRT, there is an excessive accumulation of uric acid, leading to symptoms such as joint pain, gout, and hyperuricemia. The classic symptoms of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome include severe neurological dysfunction, self-mutilating behaviors like biting fingers and lips, and elevated uric acid levels, which perfectly match the clinical scenario described in the question.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Xanthine oxidase deficiency: Xanthine oxidase is an enzyme involved in purine metabolism, specifically converting xanthine into uric acid. A deficiency would lead to low uric acid levels, not elevated levels as seen in this patient. Symptoms of self-mutilation and neurological issues are not associated with xanthine oxidase deficiency.

 

Option B. Thymidylate synthetase deficiency: Thymidylate synthetase is an enzyme involved in pyrimidine metabolism, not purine metabolism, and it does not affect uric acid levels. Deficiency would result in impaired DNA synthesis but not the symptoms seen here, such as self-mutilation and elevated uric acid.

 

Option D.  CPSII defect: CPSII (carbamoyl phosphate synthetase II) is an enzyme involved in pyrimidine synthesis. Its deficiency leads to disorders related to pyrimidine metabolism but does not cause hyperuricemia, joint pain, or self-mutilation as observed in Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:


Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is characterized by severe neurological dysfunction, self-mutilating behavior, and elevated uric acid levels due to the complete deficiency of the enzyme HGPRT.

questions.text: An elderly male presented to the clinic with fatigue, headache, backache, and renal dysfunction. He had elevated calcium levels also. His serum electrophoresis had an M spike and the immunofixation pattern has been presented alongside. What is the likely diagnosis in the patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Multiple myeloma with elevated IgM

 

The clinical presentation of an elderly male with fatigue, headache, backache, renal dysfunction, and hypercalcemia is suggestive of a plasma cell disorder, such as multiple myeloma. The key diagnostic clue is the presence of an M spike on serum electrophoresis, indicating a monoclonal gammopathy. Immunofixation Electrophoresis (IFE) separates immunoglobulin heavy and light chains:

 

  • G = IgG
  • A = IgA
  • M = IgM
  • K = Kappa light chain
  • L = Lambda light chain

 

The elevated IgM and the overproduction of kappa light chains suggest a diagnosis of lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma, commonly referred to as Waldenström's macroglobulinemia, which falls under the broader category of plasma cell cancers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Severe systemic infection: Infections usually cause polyclonal hypergammaglobulinemia, where multiple types of antibodies are elevated rather than a single monoclonal spike. The presence of monoclonality rules out this option.

 

Option B. MGUS (Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance): MGUS can present with a monoclonal spike, but it does not typically cause systemic symptoms or organ dysfunction such as renal impairment. The patient’s symptoms suggest a more severe plasma cell disorder.

 

Option C. Multiple myeloma with elevated IgG: Multiple myeloma with elevated IgG is the most common type of immunoglobulin elevated in multiple myeloma, the immunofixation pattern indicates IgM, not IgG, ruling out this choice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An M spike on serum electrophoresis along with specific symptoms and immunofixation identifying elevated IgM indicates a diagnosis of multiple myeloma or a related plasma cell cancer, such as lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma (Waldenström's macroglobulinemia).

questions.text: Glycogen phosphorylase is activated by? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Calcium

 

  • Glycogen phosphorylase is primarily activated indirectly by calcium ions. An increase in intracellular calcium levels triggers the activation of phosphorylase kinase, which, in turn, activates glycogen phosphorylase. Calcium acts as a secondary messenger to stimulate this cascade of enzymatic reactions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glucose 6 Phosphate: Glucose 6-phosphate, a product of glycogenolysis (glycogen breakdown), actually inhibits glycogen phosphorylase. It is part of a negative feedback mechanism to prevent excessive glycogen breakdown when glucose levels are sufficient.

 

Option C. Insulin: Insulin does not directly activate glycogen phosphorylase. Instead, insulin plays a role in promoting glycogen synthesis by activating glycogen synthase and inhibiting glycogen phosphorylase.

 

 

Option D. Glucose: Glucose itself does not directly activate glycogen phosphorylase. In fact, high levels of glucose signal that glucose is available for energy production, leading to the inhibition of glycogenolysis and glycogen phosphorylase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycogen phosphorylase is activated indirectly through the calcium signaling pathway, which initiates a series of enzymatic reactions ultimately leading to the activation of glycogen phosphorylase. This mechanism allows the regulation of glycogen breakdown in response to cellular energy needs.

choices.text: Chloride secretion is decreased in sweat and increased in pancreatic fluid
Chloride secretion is increased in sweat and decreased in pancreatic fluid
Chloride secretion is decreased in both sweat and pancreatic fluid
Chloride secretion is increased in both sweat and pancreatic fluid

questions.text: True regarding CF (Cystic Fibrosis): (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans B) Chloride secretion is increased in sweat and decreased in pancreatic fluid:

 

Explanation:

 

In sweat glands, the defective CFTR leads to decreased chloride reabsorption, resulting in increased chloride secretion in sweat. Therefore, individuals with CF have elevated levels of chloride in their sweat, which is a diagnostic feature of the condition.

 

In the pancreas, the impaired CFTR function leads to decreased chloride secretion into pancreatic fluid. This results in the production of thick, sticky mucus in the pancreatic ducts, leading to pancreatic insufficiency. The pancreas is unable to release digestive enzymes properly into the small intestine, affecting the digestion of food.

 

Educational objective:

 

Cystic Fibrosis (CF) is a genetic disorder caused by mutations in the CFTR (Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator) gene. CFTR is a chloride channel that regulates the movement of chloride ions across cell membranes. In individuals with cystic fibrosis, the function of CFTR is impaired.

questions.text: What is the expected MCV in CBC based on the PS image?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) > 100 fL

 

Explanation:

 

The peripheral smear (PS) image shows hypersegmented neutrophils and macro-ovalocytes, which are characteristic of megaloblastic anemia, typically due to vitamin B12 or folate deficiency. In megaloblastic anemia, the red blood cells are larger than normal, leading to an increased mean corpuscular volume (MCV).

 

Hypersegmented neutrophils are defined as neutrophils with 5 or more lobes, or at least one neutrophil with 6 or more lobes. Macro-ovalocytes are larger-than-normal red blood cells with an oval shape, which are indicative of a megaloblastic process.

 

The expected MCV in such cases is typically more than 100 fL, indicating macrocytic anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. < 80 fL: This would indicate microcytic anemia.

 

Option B. < 60 fL: This would indicate severe microcytic anemia.

 

Option C. 80-100 fL: This is the normal range for MCV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In megaloblastic anemia, characterized by the presence of hypersegmented neutrophils and macro-ovalocytes, the MCV is typically greater than 100 fL, indicating macrocytic anemia.

questions.text: The instrument given below is used to measure: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Air humidity

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a sling psychrometer, which is an instrument used to measure the water content, moisture content, or air humidity.

 

A sling psychrometer consists of two thermometers, one of which has a wet bulb (covered in a wet cloth) and the other a dry bulb. By comparing the temperatures of the wet and dry bulbs, the relative humidity can be determined using a psychrometric chart or calculation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Air temperature: While the sling psychrometer does measure air temperature using the dry bulb thermometer, its primary purpose is to measure humidity by comparing the dry and wet bulb temperatures.

 

Option B. Air velocity: The sling psychrometer is not designed to measure air velocity.

 

Option D. Cooling air: In the past, the Kata thermometer was used to measure the cooling power of air, but it is now primarily used to assess low air velocity. The sling psychrometer is not designed to measure the cooling effect of air.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sling psychrometer is an instrument used to measure air humidity by comparing the temperatures of a wet bulb and a dry bulb thermometer.

questions.text: Identify the given instrument: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wire Speculum

 

The instrument shown in the image is a wire speculum. It is characterized by its wire-like structure with two loops at the ends and a central hinge mechanism. Wire specula are commonly used in ophthalmic surgeries such as cataract surgery, glaucoma surgery, and pterygium surgery. Their primary function is to keep the eyelids apart, providing clear access to the eye during procedures. The surgeon squeezes the instrument to open it, places it between the eyelids, and then releases it to hold the lids open.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lid Clamp:  Incorrect. A lid clamp has a different structure, typically with flat surfaces for gripping the eyelid during lid surgeries like entropion or ectropion repairs.
 

 

Option C. Lid Retractor: Incorrect. A lid retractor usually has a plate-like structure at the front and a handle, used for procedures requiring broader lid retraction.

 

 

Option D. Cat's Paw Retractor: Incorrect. This instrument has a fork-like structure at the end and is commonly used in dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) surgery.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A wire speculum is a key instrument in ophthalmic surgery, used to keep the eyelids open and provide access to the eye during various procedures. Its characteristic wire-like structure with loops at the ends distinguishes it from other lid manipulation instruments.

choices.text: Do ultrasound for gestational age, check for abnormalities, check sex, and tell the mother.
Do ultrasound for gestational age, check for abnormalities, check sex but don’t tell the mother.
Do ultrasound for gestational age, check for abnormalities, don’t check the sex.
Don’t do ultrasound, do ANC only.

questions.text: A 28-year-old G5L4 with all 4-girl children presents at 18 weeks and asks for the sex of the child on ultrasound. This is her first antenatal visit. What should be done? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Do ultrasound for gestational age, check for abnormalities, don’t check the sex.


The Ans. is C because, according to the Pre-Conception and Pre-Natal Diagnostic Techniques (PCPNDT) Act, sex determination of the fetus is illegal and punishable by law. At 18 weeks, the primary purpose of the ultrasound is to assess gestational age and check for any fetal abnormalities as part of the anomaly scan. Checking or revealing the sex of the fetus is prohibited and carries legal consequences. Therefore, the healthcare provider should perform the ultrasound for the medical purposes it is intended for and avoid even viewing the sex of the fetus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Do ultrasound for gestational age, check for abnormalities, check sex, and tell the mother: is incorrect because checking the sex and informing the mother is illegal under the PCPNDT Act, and can lead to legal repercussions, including imprisonment.

 

Option B. Do ultrasound for gestational age, check for abnormalities, check sex but don’t tell the mother: is also incorrect. Even looking at the fetus’s sex, regardless of whether it is disclosed, is a violation of the law and is punishable.

 

Option D. Don’t do ultrasound, do ANC only: is incorrect because the ultrasound at 18 weeks is necessary for evaluating gestational age and detecting any fetal abnormalities, which are critical aspects of prenatal care.

 

Educational Objective:


The key point to remember is that checking or revealing the sex of the fetus during an ultrasound is illegal under the PCPNDT Act. The ultrasound should only be used for assessing fetal gestational age and abnormalities.

questions.text:
Chronic HBV infection would be consistent with which of the following serology? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. HBsAg
  2. Anti-HBsAg
  3. Anti-HBcAg
  4. HBV DNA
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 3, 4

 

Anti-HBs (Hepatitis B surface antibody): This antibody appears after the infection has been cleared or following successful vaccination. It indicates immunity to HBV. In chronic HBV infection, this antibody is not present since the surface antigen is still active.

 

Chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection is defined by the persistence of the surface antigen (HBsAg) for more than six months. The presence of HBsAg indicates an active HBV infection.

 

Serological markers:

 

1. HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen): This antigen indicates that the person is infectious. It is found in the blood during acute and chronic HBV infection. The presence of HBsAg for more than six months defines chronic HBV infection.

 

3. Anti-HBc (Hepatitis B core antibody): This antibody indicates previous or ongoing infection with HBV. In chronic infection, the IgG fraction of anti-HBc is usually present.

 

4. HBV DNA: The presence of HBV DNA in the blood indicates active viral replication. It is usually detectable in chronic HBV infection, although the levels can vary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic HBV infection is characterized by the persistence of HBsAg, the presence of Anti-HBc, and usually detectable HBV DNA. Anti-HBs is not present in chronic HBV infection as it indicates immunity.

questions.text: Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is involved in the hyperacute rejection of renal transplants? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Type II

 

Hyperacute graft rejection is an example of type II hypersensitivity reaction.

 

It is mediated by preformed antibodies. It is a rare event that occurs in kidney transplantation.

 

This results in rapid, severe, and often irreversible damage to the transplanted kidney, leading to graft failure. The preformed antibodies are usually directed against specific antigens on the endothelial cells of the donor organ.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type IV: Incorrect, Type IV hypersensitivity is a delayed reaction mediated by T cells, not antibodies, and is not responsible for hyperacute rejection.

 

Option B. Type III: Incorrect, Type III hypersensitivity involves immune complexes (antigen-antibody complexes) that can deposit in tissues and cause inflammation but is not the mechanism behind hyperacute rejection.

 

Option D. Type I: Incorrect, Type I hypersensitivity is an immediate allergic reaction (like asthma or anaphylaxis) mediated by IgE antibodies, which is different from the antibody-mediated attack on transplanted organs seen in hyperacute rejection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type II hypersensitivity is crucial in the context of hyperacute rejection of renal transplants, highlighting the importance of thorough pre-transplant screening for donor-specific antibodies to avoid this rapid and destructive immune response.

questions.text:
The fibres of the internal oblique muscle and transversus abdominus muscle contribute to which boundaries of the inguinal canal walls? (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  1. Anterior wall
  2. Roof
  3. Floor
  4. Posterior wall
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ii and iv

 

 

 

The inguinal canal is an important structure in the anterior abdominal wall, with specific boundaries formed by different layers of muscles and fascia. The internal oblique is present in the lateral 1/3rd of anterior wall but transverse abdominis does not contribute to the anterior wall at all.

 

ii. Roof: The fibres of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles, along with their conjoint tendon, form the roof of the inguinal canal.

 

iv. Posterior wall: The conjoint tendon, formed by the joining of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles, also contributes to the posterior wall of the inguinal canal.

 

Other Options:

 

i. Anterior wall: The anterior wall of the inguinal canal is primarily formed by the external oblique aponeurosis, along with skin and superficial fascia. The internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles do not contribute to the anterior wall.

 

iii. Floor: The floor of the inguinal canal is formed by the inguinal ligament, not by the internal oblique or transversus abdominis muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles contribute to the roof and posterior wall of the inguinal canal through their conjoint tendon.

questions.text: A patient had a pulmonary mass which shows IHC staining with TTF-1 as shown in the image. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adenocarcinoma lung

 

Thyroid Transcription Factor-1 (TTF-1) is a nuclear protein that is a specific marker for adenocarcinoma of the lung and small cell carcinoma of the lung. However, it is most commonly associated with adenocarcinoma.

 

TTF-1 positivity indicates that the tumor cells are likely of lung or thyroid origin, with adenocarcinoma being the most common type of lung cancer associated with this marker.

 

Additionally, other markers like Napsin A and surfactant protein A1 are also specific to adenocarcinoma of the lung.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Squamous cell cancer lung: Squamous cell carcinoma typically shows markers like P63, P40, or keratin. It does not stain positive for TTF-1, differentiating it from adenocarcinoma.

 

Option C. Small cell carcinoma lung: While TTF-1 can be positive in small cell carcinoma, other specific markers such as chromogranin, synaptophysin, and INSM-1 are more indicative. TTF-1's presence alone, along with the given context, makes adenocarcinoma the more likely diagnosis.

 

Option D. Large cell carcinoma lung: This is generally a diagnosis of exclusion and does not have specific immunohistochemical markers like TTF-1. Large cell carcinoma is generally a diagnosis of exclusion, as it lacks specific markers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TTF-1 is a key immunohistochemical marker that strongly suggests adenocarcinoma of the lung, particularly when observed in a pulmonary mass.

choices.text: Severe malnutrition - refer to nutrition rehabilitation center
Moderate malnutrition - teach the mother on how to feed

questions.text: A 16-month-old boy is found to weigh 8kg. A WHO growth chart (weight-for-height) is provided below. Plot the growth chart for this child. What is the most appropriate advice based on the plotted graph? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Moderate malnutrition - teach the mother on how to feed

 

The WHO growth chart (weight-for-height) shows that the weight of 8 kg for a 16-month-old boy falls between -2 standard deviations (SD) and -3 SD, indicating moderate malnutrition. This suggests that the child is not receiving adequate nutrition and is at risk for growth and developmental delays.

 

In such cases, it is important to educate the mother on proper feeding practices to ensure the child receives a balanced diet with adequate nutrients. This can involve guidance on meal frequency, food variety, and portion sizes to improve the child's nutritional status.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. No malnutrition - Assure the mother: This option is incorrect because the child’s weight for height falls between -2SD and -3SD on the growth chart, indicating moderate malnutrition rather than no malnutrition.

 

Option B. Mild malnutrition - home treatment: This option is incorrect as mild malnutrition is indicated when the weight-for-height is between -1SD and -2SD. The child’s weight falls between -2SD and -3SD, indicating moderate malnutrition.

 

Option C. Severe malnutrition - refer to nutrition rehabilitation center: This option is incorrect because severe malnutrition is diagnosed when the weight-for-height is less than -3SD. The child’s weight does not fall into this category.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Moderate malnutrition in children is indicated by a weight-for-height between -2SD and -3SD on the WHO growth chart, necessitating education on proper feeding practices.

questions.text: A farmer with a history of prick injury came with the complaint: swelling of the foot with sinus tracts showing pus discharge, which showed white granules and gram-positive filamentous structures were noted on microscopy. What is the most likely causative organism associated? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nocardia brasiliensis

 

This clinical scenario involving a farmer, a common occupation associated with exposure to organisms causing subcutaneous infections. The key clues here are:

 

  1. Prick injury: Suggests a subcutaneous mycosis or actinomycetoma.
  2. Swelling of the foot with sinus tracts, pus discharge, and white granules: These are characteristic features of mycetoma, also known as Madura foot.
  3. Gram-positive filamentous structures on microscopy: This is a hallmark of actinomycetoma, specifically caused by bacterial agents like Nocardia brasiliensis.

 

Mycetoma is classified into two types based on the causative organism: Actinomycetoma and Eumycetoma

 

 

Given the presence of gram-positive filamentous structures and white granules, the most likely causative organism is Nocardia brasiliensis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sporothrix schenckii: Incorrect because it causes sporotrichosis, a subcutaneous mycosis, but does not produce granules or gram-positive filamentous structures.

 

Option B. Staphylococcus aureus: Incorrect because, although it is gram-positive and can cause abscesses and sinus tracts, it does not form filamentous structures and is not typically associated with granules as seen in mycetoma.

 

Option D. Aspergillus: Incorrect because it is a fungus that can cause invasive infections, especially in immunocompromised individuals, but does not match the presentation described (i.e., white granules and gram-positive filaments).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mycetoma, or Madura foot, caused by Nocardia brasiliensis, presents with swelling, sinus tracts, white granules, and gram-positive filamentous structures on microscopy, distinguishing it from eumycetoma and other subcutaneous infections.

questions.text: A patient was undergoing surgery under general anesthesia. For intubation, 90 mg of rocuronium was given, but the anesthesiologist was unable to intubate the patient. What is the drug given for immediate reversal of the neuromuscular blockade? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sugammadex

 

Sugammadex is specifically designed to reverse the effects of rocuronium and vecuronium, which are non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents used during anesthesia. Rocuronium works by blocking acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, leading to muscle paralysis. Sugammadex, a γ-cyclodextrin compound, encapsulates the rocuronium molecules, effectively removing them from the neuromuscular junction. This action results in the immediate reversal of muscle paralysis, allowing the patient to regain normal muscle function. Sugammadex is unique because it can rapidly reverse the effects of rocuronium, even if the drug was administered only moments earlier, which is crucial in situations where intubation fails and the patient needs to recover quickly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neostigmine: Neostigmine is used to reverse non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers like rocuronium, but it is not effective immediately after the drug has been administered. Neostigmine works by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase, thereby increasing acetylcholine levels at the neuromuscular junction to outcompete the blocking agent. However, for neostigmine to be effective, a significant amount of the neuromuscular blocking agent must have already dissociated from the receptors, which typically happens toward the end of the surgery, not immediately after administration.

 

Option C. Glycopyrrolate: Glycopyrrolate is often used in conjunction with neostigmine to counteract the muscarinic side effects of increased acetylcholine, such as bradycardia. However, glycopyrrolate itself does not reverse neuromuscular blockade and cannot be used to immediately counteract the effects of rocuronium.

 

Option D. Atropine: Atropine, like glycopyrrolate, is used to mitigate the side effects of cholinesterase inhibitors like neostigmine. It does not reverse neuromuscular blockade directly and is not effective in immediately reversing the effects of rocuronium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sugammadex is the specific and immediate antidote for the reversal of rocuronium-induced neuromuscular blockade. It is unique in its ability to rapidly and effectively reverse paralysis even shortly after rocuronium administration, making it the drug of choice in emergency situations where rapid recovery of muscle function is required.

questions.text: Name the joint formed between the epiphysis and diaphysis of a long bone: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Synchondrosis

 

The joint formed between the epiphysis and diaphysis of a long bone is known as a synchondrosis. Synchondrosis is a type of primary cartilaginous joint where bones are joined by hyaline cartilage. In the context of long bones, this joint occurs between the epiphyseal plate (growth plate) and the diaphysis during the development of the bone.

 

The epiphyseal plate is a layer of hyaline cartilage that allows the bone to grow in length. As growth continues, this cartilage eventually undergoes ossification, transforming into bone and thereby eliminating the synchondrosis joint, marking the end of growth in length.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syndesmosis: This is a fibrous joint where bones are connected by a ligament or a sheet of fibrous tissue. It does not involve cartilage and is therefore not applicable to the junction between the epiphysis and diaphysis.

 

Option C. Synarthrosis: Synarthrosis refers to an immovable joint. While synchondrosis could be considered a type of synarthrosis when ossified, it specifically refers to the cartilaginous joint prior to ossification. Thus, this option is less specific and not the correct answer in this context.

 

Option D. Symphysis: Symphysis is a secondary cartilaginous joint where bones are joined by fibrocartilage. It is typically found in the midline of the body, such as the pubic symphysis or the intervertebral discs. This type of joint does not describe the connection between the epiphysis and diaphysis of a long bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The joint formed between the epiphysis and diaphysis of a long bone during development is a synchondrosis, which is a primary cartilaginous joint composed of hyaline cartilage that eventually ossifies as growth completes.

questions.text: Based on the depiction in the accompanying image, which model of disease causation is being illustrated? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Sufficient component cause model 

 

  • The model of disease causation depicted is a sufficient component cause model.
  • It was developed by Rothman based on the idea that an outcome can only happen when a sufficient cause is present.
  • A disease can have multiple sufficient causes. But each sufficient cause can consist of a pie chart of component causes, a causal pie.
  • One component cause can be a part of more than one sufficient cause.
  • A component cause can be considered necessary if it is a part of a disease's sufficient causes.
  • In the given model, each pie chart represents a sufficient cause made of component causes.
  • Since B is present in all the charts, it can be considered a necessary cause. All the others are contributing causes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Epidemiological triad: An epidemiological triad depicts the interrelationship between the causative agent, the host, and the environment. All of them contribute to disease development. The aim of an epidemiological triad is to identify how to break this relationship and prevent the outbreak of the disease.

 

Option C. PERT model: PERT is used for network analysis. It is a type of quantitative management technique that helps in detailed planning and comprehensive supervision.

 

 

Option D. Web of causation model: The web of causation considers all the predisposing factors and their complex interrelationship with each other. This model is ideally suited to study chronic disease. The web of causation does not imply that the disease is controlled only when all the multiple chains of causation are removed.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sufficient component cause model illustrates how multiple factors contribute to disease causation, with some factors being necessary components in multiple causal pathways.

questions.text: A child was being delivered oxygen by nasal canula at 3L/min. What is the FiO2 being delivered?  (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B.  30%

 

Explanation:

 

The fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) delivered by nasal cannula increases by approximately 4% for every 1 liter per minute of oxygen flow. Thus:

 

  • 1 L/min would raise the FiO2 to about 24%.
  • 2 L/min would be about 28%.
  • 3 L/min would be about 32%.

 

Given the options provided, the closest and most commonly accepted approximation for the FiO2 being delivered at a flow rate of 3 L/min through a nasal cannula would be around 30%.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 25%: This FiO2 would typically correspond to an oxygen flow rate of about 1 L/min via nasal cannula.

 

Option C. 40%: This FiO2 would typically correspond to an oxygen flow rate of about 5 L/min via nasal cannula.

 

Option D. 45%: This FiO2 would typically correspond to an oxygen flow rate of about 6 L/min via nasal cannula.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The FiO2 delivered by a nasal cannula at a flow rate of 3 L/min is approximately 30%.

questions.text: Identify the papillae from the given histological section: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Circumvallate

 

  • The given histological image is a section of the tongue displaying circumvallate papillae, which are the largest papillae present on the tongue.
  • They are cylindrical in shape, and usually around 8-12 in no.
  • They are covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium and are arranged in a V-shaped row immediately in front of the sulcus terminalis on the dorsal surface of the tongue.
  • They are narrower at their base than their apex and contain numerous taste buds (around 250 for each papilla) within their walls. These taste buds contain chemosensory cells that synapse with the gustatory nerves, enabling the sense of taste.
  • In addition, the serous glands of von Ebner empty via ducts into the base of the sulcus, which helps to flush out food particles from the area surrounding the papillae.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Fungiform papillae are protrusions on the tongue that are relatively large, round, and reddish in color. They can be found on both the dorsal surface and the lingual margins of the tongue, and are covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium.

 

Option C: Filiform papillae are small, conical or cylindrical projections located mainly on the dorsal surface of the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. They lack taste buds and are covered by keratinized stratified squamous epithelium. All other papillae, except filiform, contain taste buds.

 

Option D: Foliate papillae are red, leaf-like mucosal ridges located bilaterally in two zones at the sides of the tongue near the sulcus terminalis. They are covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Circumvallate papilla are located on the dorsum of the tongue, forming a V-shaped row in front of the terminal sulcus (the V-shaped groove that separates the anterior two-thirds from the posterior third of the tongue). They are the largest papillae, about 8-12 in number, and have a round, raised shape. Each is surrounded by a trench (or moat), hence the name 'circumvallate.

choices.text: Lower border of the upper rib
Upper border of the lower rib
Lower border of the lower rib

questions.text: What is the most preferred site for the needle insertion into the thoracic cavity for the pleural fluid removal? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Upper border of the lower rib

 

Explanation:

 

The most preferred site for needle insertion during a thoracentesis (removal of pleural fluid) is along the upper border of the lower rib within the intercostal space. This is because the neurovascular bundle (vein, artery, and nerve) runs along the lower border of each rib within the costal groove. Inserting the needle at the upper border of the lower rib minimizes the risk of damaging these vital structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lower border of the upper rib: Inserting the needle here would increase the risk of injuring the neurovascular bundle within the costal groove of the upper rib.

 

Option C. Lower border of the lower rib: This would also pose a high risk of damaging the neurovascular bundle.

 

Option D. Middle of the intercostal space: Inserting the needle here does not provide a safe margin away from the neurovascular structures and could still lead to injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For thoracentesis, always insert the needle at the upper border of the lower rib in the intercostal space to avoid damaging the neurovascular bundle located in the costal groove of the upper rib.

questions.text:
What are the components of Nada's Minor Criteria? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Systolic mumur Grade 3
  2. Diastolic murmur
  3. Abnormal second heart sound
  4. Abnormal BP
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3 and 4

 

Nada’s criteria is used for detection of CHD on the basis of clinical evaluation.

 

 

Presence of 1 major or 2 minor criteria suggest presence of heart disease.

 

Educational Objective:
 

In Nada’s criteria for detecting congenital heart disease, minor criteria include an abnormal second heart sound and abnormal blood pressure. The presence of one major or two minor criteria suggests the presence of heart disease.
